subhead: 'Our planet at +1.5°C' (5/6) The Mekong Delta and Ho Chi Minh City, home to a third of Vietnam's population, face rising seas and the toll of decades of resource overuse, leaving much of the delta at risk of submersion.

'The Louvre theft marks a turning point between a hampered public cultural scene and wealthy, private players'
subhead: As the Musée du Louvre falls victim to a break-in, the art world gathers at the dazzling Fondation Cartier, enjoys itself at the Art Basel Paris fair, and marvels at exhibitions at the Fondation Louis Vuitton and the Pinault Collection, writes Le Monde columnist Michel Guerrin.

headline: 40 million Americans face food stamp disruption amid shutdown
subhead: Today, around one in eight Americans receives Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits each month based on income, according to the Department of Agriculture. In the event of non-payment, states have invited recipients to make use of food banks, which could be swiftly overwhelmed by the demand.

headline: Beware of food poisoning from Halloween pumpkins
subhead: Every year, dozens of people in France suffer mainly digestive symptoms after eating inedible squash. The biochemical origins of this plant toxicity are now better understood.

headline: A dizzying dive into Bob Wilson's Long Island theater of objects
subhead: Famous for his groundbreaking shows, the American stage director, who died this summer at the age of 83, was also a great lover of art and design. A compulsive collector of chairs, which he created for his productions, he left behind thousands of works gathered throughout his life, spread between his Manhattan loft-studio, storage warehouses and the Water Mill art center, which he founded on Long Island.

Jacques-Louis David, at home in the Louvre
subhead: The exhibition at the Paris museum brings together around a hundred works, paintings and drawings, including some on loan from Brussels, where the artist sought refuge after the Bourbon Restoration.

headline: 'Airbnb has shaped the idea that everything can be monetized. It's a logic of constant optimization'
subhead: 'The Airbnb Ogre' (2/6). In Paris, about one-third of the listings available on Airbnb have been removed from the 'permanent' housing market, which contributes to the housing crisis in the French capital, explains researcher Jeanne Richon in an interview with Le Monde.

headline: Too old to get a job, too young to retire: The French women over 50 stuck in limbo
subhead: In France, 21% of people aged 55-61 struggle to find work but are unable to retire. Women, who suffer more from societal inequalities throughout their career, are particularly at risk.
